full_conversation: Therapist: Let's begin our imaginal exposure session. Can you describe the event we've been working on?
Client: Okay... It was the day of the earthquake. I was at home, getting ready for work. I remember feeling the ground start to shake...
Therapist: You're doing well. Continue describing what happened.
Client: The shaking got stronger. I could hear things falling and breaking. I tried to get to the doorway, but I stumbled. The noise was deafening. I was terrified...
Therapist: Stay with that moment. You're safe here.
Client: I... I'm not sure I can do this. My heart is racing just thinking about it.
Therapist: Take a deep breath. You're handling this well.
Client: Okay... The walls were creaking, and I thought the ceiling might collapse. I curled up in the doorway, covering my head. I felt so helpless...
Therapist: You're very brave. Keep going.
Client: I could hear screaming from outside. The power went out, and it was dark. I was alone, and I didn't know if it would ever stop. I kept thinking about my ex-partner, wishing they were there...
Therapist: It's okay to feel those emotions. You're doing great.
Client: But they weren't there. We had broken up just a month before. I felt so abandoned, so vulnerable. The shaking seemed to last forever...
Therapist: You're handling this memory well. Continue.
Client: When it finally stopped, I was too scared to move. I sat there, shaking, for what felt like hours. The aftershocks kept coming. I tried calling my ex, but the lines were down...
Therapist: You're showing great strength. How are you feeling right now?
Client: I feel... overwhelmed. My palms are sweaty, and my chest feels tight. But... I also feel a bit relieved to be talking about it.
Therapist: That's completely normal. You're doing excellent work.
Client: Thank you. It's hard, but... I want to continue. After a while, I finally got up. The apartment was a mess. Broken glass everywhere, furniture toppled. I made my way outside...
Therapist: You're very courageous. Keep going.

Client: The street was chaos. People crying, buildings damaged. I felt so alone in the crowd. I kept thinking if only my ex was there, I'd feel safer. But they weren't, and I had to face this alone...
Therapist: It's okay to have felt that way. You're safe now.
Client: I know, but it's still hard. I found some neighbors I knew, and we huddled together. We were all in shock. The aftershocks kept coming, and each time, I felt that same terror...
Therapist: You're doing really well. How are you feeling now?
Client: I'm... I'm okay. My heart is still racing, but I feel like I can breathe a bit easier. Talking about it... it's helping, I think.
Therapist: That's great progress. Would you like to continue?
Client: Yes, I think so. We stayed outside for hours. Emergency services started arriving. I kept checking my phone, hoping for a message from my ex, but nothing came. I felt so abandoned...
Therapist: It's understandable you felt that way. You're handling this memory well.
Client: Thanks. As night fell, it got colder. We were told it wasn't safe to go back inside. I had to sleep in a makeshift shelter. I've never felt so alone and scared in my life...
Therapist: You're showing incredible strength. How do you feel now?
Client: I feel... drained, but also a bit lighter. Like I've released some of the weight I've been carrying. It's still painful, but... maybe a bit less overwhelming?
Therapist: That's excellent progress. You should be proud of yourself.
Client: Thank you. I never thought I'd be able to talk about this without completely falling apart. It's still hard, but... I think I'm starting to see that I can handle these memories.
Therapist: You've done remarkable work today. How would you like to proceed?
Client: I think... I'd like to stop here for now. It feels like a good place to pause. Is that okay?
Therapist: Absolutely. You've made significant progress today.
Client: Thank you. I appreciate your support through this. It means a lot to have someone listen and understand.
Therapist: You're welcome. Let's take a moment to ground ourselves before we end.
Client: Okay. I'm feeling more centered now. Thank you for guiding me through this. I'm looking forward to our next session, even though I know it will be challenging.
Therapist: That's a great attitude. We'll end here for today.
